title: Elijah on Mount Carmel
shortSummary: In 1 Kings 18, the prophet Elijah confronts King Ahab and the prophets of Baal during a severe famine in Israel. Through a dramatic contest on Mount Carmel, Elijah demonstrates the power of the one true God, leading to the defeat of Baal's prophets and the end of the drought by God's abundant rain. This chapter highlights God's sovereignty, the call to faithfulness, and the power of prayer.
timeline: c. 870 BC - Reign of King Ahab in Israel during the divided monarchy

keyCharacters.name: Elijah
keyCharacters.description: A prophet of the LORD who boldly challenges Baal worship and calls Israel back to faithfulness.

keyCharacters.name: Ahab
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who has led the nation into idolatry, particularly the worship of Baal.

keyCharacters.name: Obadiah
keyCharacters.description: Ahab's house governor who fears the LORD and secretly protects 100 prophets from Jezebel's persecution.

keyCharacters.name: Prophets of Baal
keyCharacters.description: Four hundred and fifty false prophets who serve Baal and oppose the LORD's prophet Elijah.

definitions.definition: A Canaanite deity worshiped as a god of rain, fertility, and storms, falsely worshiped by Israel under Ahab's reign.
False prophets associated with the worship of Asherah or other pagan deities, often linked to sacred trees or groves.
A sacred structure where sacrifices are made to God, symbolizing worship and covenant relationship.
A daily ritual in Israel's temple worship occurring at twilight, symbolizing continual devotion to God.

outline.heading: God's Word to Elijah and the Famine Context
outline.description: God commands Elijah to present himself to Ahab after three years of drought, setting the stage for divine intervention amid a severe famine.

outline.heading: Elijah and Obadiah's Encounter
outline.description: Elijah reveals himself to Obadiah, who fears for his life but faithfully serves God by protecting prophets; Elijah assures Obadiah of his mission to confront Ahab.

outline.heading: Challenge to the Prophets of Baal
outline.description: Elijah confronts Ahab and challenges the prophets of Baal to a contest on Mount Carmel to prove who is the true God, exposing Baal's impotence.

outline.heading: Elijah's Prayer and God's Fiery Response
outline.description: Elijah repairs the LORD's altar, prays for God to reveal His power, and God answers by sending fire to consume the sacrifice, confirming His sovereignty.

outline.heading: Judgment on Baal's Prophets and End of the Drought
outline.description: Elijah orders the execution of Baal's prophets, announces the coming rain, and prays for rain, resulting in a heavy downpour that ends the famine.

application: Trust in God's timing and faithfulness even during prolonged trials, as Elijah waited three years before God's word came to him.
Stand boldly for the truth of God in a culture that often promotes false beliefs, following Elijah's example of courage and conviction.
Commit to persistent and fervent prayer, recognizing that God hears and answers according to His will, as seen in Elijah's prayers for fire and rain.
Be faithful in protecting and supporting God's servants and truth, like Obadiah who risked his life to hide the prophets.

keyVerses.text: And Elijah came unto all the people, and said, How long halt ye between two opinions? if the LORD be God, follow him: but if Baal, then follow him. And the people answered him not a word.
keyVerses.significance: This verse challenges believers to fully commit to God rather than wavering between faith and compromise.

keyVerses.text: And it came to pass at the time of the offering of the evening sacrifice, that Elijah the prophet came near, and said, LORD God of Abraham, Isaac, and of Israel, let it be known this day that thou art God in Israel, and that I am thy servant, and that I have done all these things at thy word. Hear me, O LORD, hear me, that this people may know that thou art the LORD God, and that thou hast turned their heart back again.
keyVerses.significance: Elijah's prayer exemplifies humble dependence on God and a desire for God's glory and the people's repentance.

keyVerses.text: Then the fire of the LORD fell, and consumed the burnt sacrifice, and the wood, and the stones, and the dust, and licked up the water that was in the trench.
keyVerses.significance: God's miraculous fire powerfully confirms His sovereignty and validates Elijah's prophetic ministry.

keyVerses.text: And Elijah said unto Ahab, Get thee up, eat and drink; for there is a sound of abundance of rain. So Ahab went up to eat and to drink. And Elijah went up to the top of Carmel; and he cast himself down upon the earth, and put his face between his knees, And said to his servant, Go up now, look toward the sea. And he went up, and looked, and said, There is nothing. And he said, Go again seven times. And it came to pass at the seventh time, that he said, Behold, there ariseth a little cloud out of the sea, like a man's hand. And he said, Go up, say unto Ahab, Prepare thy chariot, and get thee down, that the rain stop thee not. And it came to pass in the mean while, that the heaven was black with clouds and wind, and there was a great rain. And Ahab rode, and went to Jezreel.
keyVerses.significance: This passage shows the power of persistent faith and prayer, resulting in God's gracious provision and restoration.
